title: Geth Runs for 15-20min and Syncs SOME, but then stops.
body:
I apologize if I'm putting this is the wrong place, but I have tried a few of the solutions from around the internet (i.e. different modifiers when running Geth), but have had no luck. It's like it runs for a while then tries to update or pull new files from Git? And eventually exits. Each time I check and see that it has exited, this is all that is still in the Terminal Window for a log after running the command "sudo geth --datadir /mnt/ssd/ethereum --vmodule=downloader=6" :

Sorry, we need the beginning of the stacktrace to know what the problem is. Usually it says `panic: ...` at the beginning.

Also, you should not run geth as root.

You're probably running out of memory. If you have 8GB of RAM and have cache set to 4GB, then you're running out of memory. Geth (and all programs written in Go) use **at least** 2x the memory you allocate 'for efficient garbage collection'. If you have 8GB of system memory, you can probably get away with a 3GB cache, but 2GB is more likely to work. I have 16GB and Geth will eat up 12GB with a 4GB --cache setting.

Thank you both very much! I was able to get Geth to run without root, as I kind of realized it's because of the directory that I'm mounting the disk to? At least, I think that's what's going on here. So, this is what I did and it got Geth to run without root and not crash, because I also added the cache argument. However, it seems whether I put 256 or 2048, it doesn't matter... it seems to only use about the following resources and only get as synchronized about this far. Do I just need to wait longer? Is there a way to make use of more of my RAM? Thanks in advance, you guys are very helpful!
![GethPI](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/58410767/119590302-7cbc5100-bda2-11eb-8140-4a8b32073cea.JPG)


sudo chown -R pi /mnt/ssd/

sudo mount /dev/sda /mnt/ssd

sudo geth --cache 2048 --datadir /mnt/ssd/ethereum

The stacktrace you posted first points to some problem, but since it was incomplete, there's not much we can read out from it. The last screenshot shows things working normally, so doesn't help much. 

If your terminal buffer is too small to catch the full stacktrace, perhaps you can try running it and pipe the output to file. I don't know how it's usually performed in windows, the unix way would be `geth <args> 2>&1>log.file`
